items.title: Composed Modal with Tooltip: tooltip info sometimes visible after modal close

labels.name: severity: 2
labels.description: Affects major functionality, has a workaround

items.body:
### Package

carbon-components-react

### Browser

Chrome

### Package version

v7.54.1

### React version

_No response_

### Description

When rendering a `Tooltip` inside a `ComposedModal` there is unexpected behavior upon close.

Example:
If you click on the tooltip to display its information, but then do not click it again to close it and then proceed to close the modal (by clicking anywhere over the tooltip, not by clicking the 'x' button or pressing escape), the tooltip textbox will still be visible after the modal disappears. You will then have to click 1 more time outside the lingering tooltip message to make it go away. 


### CodeSandbox example

https://codesandbox.io/s/composed-modal-with-tooltip-possible-issue-n3gmhm?file=/src/index.js

- Click to show the full tooltip inside of the ComposedModal

![composed modal with tooltip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58742933/157101482-03a579b6-ac21-4dff-8fcf-e5207fce2f2f.png)

- Click on the tooltip (the text, box, or arrow area)

![leftover tooltip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58742933/157101328-7da64ef8-d55f-4a53-a6a8-369b52f702ac.png)

items.title: Two factor confirmation modal
items.body:
**Description:** 
Two-factor confirmation for consequential tasks/actions. 

**Overview:** 
For tasks/actions that pose a liability if performed on the wrong resource, a two-factor confirmation can help users reduce the risk of selecting the wrong one.

![2fc1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723185-5a863e25-741f-4cee-b6dd-72d78c65c0b6.png)
_Current pattern (one-factor or one-click confirmation)_



![2fc2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723248-3400bbaa-8787-4cd0-af1a-cc5f898deece.png)
_New pattern with confirmation checkbox for one resource (two-factor or two-click confirmation)_



![2fc3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723265-5176b8d4-38de-4e79-bb1b-163e8c3b2222.png)
_New pattern with confirmation checkbox for many resources (two-factor or two-click confirmation)_


**When to use** 
- High-risk actions that cause a liability if performed on the wrong resource 
- Tasks/actions that cannot be easily reverted back 
- Tasks/actions that affect a significant amount of data or sensitive data 

**When not to use**
- Low risk tasks/actions that have inconsequential effects or that can be easily reversed 

**Behaviors** 
The confirmation checkbox is disabled by default. 

In the case of multi-select, resources can be removed from the list by clicking the ‚Äúx‚Äù.

![2ffc4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723446-b125162b-af55-43c6-a899-4c7c18e37537.png)


If applicable, warning messages appear at the top of the window and include information about what the problems is and the solution to fix it. Do not state the obvious. 

In the case of multi-select, those resources effected by the warning message appear disabled in the list. These disabled resources can be removed from the list by clicking the ‚Äúx‚Äù; but this isn‚Äôt necessary since the task/action will only be performed on those resources that appear enabled in the list.

![2fc5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723512-af6d63ae-e6c4-4731-8ca7-5235e9a02539.png)


Selecting the confirmation checkbox causes the primary button to become enabled.

![2fc6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723556-4eb4071e-bf88-4937-ac5f-9d1c8ce45449.png)


The confirmation checkbox should always be the last component on the form.

![2fc7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96617414/148723584-24352cfd-85f8-4391-84dd-76c205724098.png)


**Best practices** 
- Describe the consequence/s of the task/action that the user needs to be aware of; do not state the obvious 
- If single select, provide the name of the resource to be affected 
- If multi-select, display the number and type of resources to be affected, and display the list of resource names to be affected; including additional identifiers if needed 

**Keyboard navigation and accessibility** 
Follow existing keyboard navigation and accessibility guidelines for modals.

items.title: [Bug]: The specified padding for modal dialogs differs from the refrence implementation
items.body:
### Package

carbon-components

### Browser

_No response_

### Package version

11

### React version

_No response_

### Description

The specification calls for 20% right margin for body copy within the dialog.
The diagram indicates that this 20% is measured from the edge of the container, which overlaps with 16px standard padding.
![](https://www.carbondesignsystem.com/static/78b566592912c237b8ca9a5bd7ec5b82/3cbba/modal-style-2.png)

The reference implementation has a 20% right padding measured from the left edge of the standard 16px padding

### CodeSandbox example

https://react.carbondesignsystem.com/iframe.html?id=components-modal--default&args=&viewMode=story

### Steps to reproduce

Inspect the paragraph styling showing the 20% right padding:
.cds--modal-content p, .cds--modal-content__regular-content
padding-right: 20%;

And the padding for the outer div container:
.cds--modal-content
padding-right: 1rem;

Assuming a 1000px wide dialog.
The specification indicates that there should be 200px (20%) padding between the right of the text and the right edge of the dialog.
Assuming the same 1000px wide dialog with the reference implementation:
Inner Content Width = 1000 - 16px (left) - 16 px (right) = 968 px
Inner Content padding = 20% of the Inner Content Width = 20% of 968px = 193.6px
The padding between the right of the text and the right edge of the dialog would be 193.6px + 16 px = 209.6px

Please resolve if the specification or the reference implementation is "correct"

If I get a vote, the reference implementation would be easier for us to adopt into our product's usage.
:)

items.title: Modal does not have affirmative exit motion
items.body:
### Summary

The [Carbon Motion Design Guideline](https://www.carbondesignsystem.com/guidelines/motion/choreography#consistency) states that "Use motion to reinforce meaning. Affirmative action here triggers a different exit motion for the modal than negation". However this is not implemented in the Modal component: it only has a [-24px transform variant](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/blob/8f3c2a122e42bbb0716f3ad7778f5617600beefb/packages/components/src/components/modal/_modal.scss#L83), so it always appear/disappear in the top direction.

Implementing this in CSS should be quite simple; all it needs is a class for +24px variant. However, I'm not sure what how one should design the component APIs/props for this.

items.title: [Bug]: bx--body--with-modal-open behaviour is incorrect when there are multiple <Modal>s
items.body:
### Package

carbon-components-react

### Browser

Chrome

### Package version

7.46.0

### Description

The `<Modal>` component has functionality in `componentDidMount`, `componentDidUpdate` and `componentWillUnmount` to add or remove the `.bx--body--with-modal-open` class to the `<body>` element. The idea is that if the `<Modal>` is open (*i.e.* its `open` prop is truthy), the class is added; if it is not open, the class is removed. The purpose of the class seems to be to suppress the `<body>` element's scrollbar and prevent scrolling.

This works fine when there is only one `<Modal>` on the page, but if there are two, it goes wrong. Suppose they are both closed at first. Then the first `<Modal>` opens. It adds the `.bx--body--with-modal-open` class to the `<body>` element. So far so good.

Now suppose the second `<Modal>` re-renders. It doesn't *open* - having two `<Modal>`'s open at the same time is frowned upon, as we know - it doesn't even need to change state or props. It just *re-renders*. This causes the second `<Modal>`'s `componentDidUpdate` to get hit. It discovers that its own `open` prop is closed - still - and it obediently removes the `.bx--body--with-modal-open` class from the `<body>` element... even though the first `<Modal>` is still open and the class should still be there.

In practical terms this has the effect of making a scrollbar on the overall page disappear and reappear at seemingly random times while the first `<Modal>` is open.

### CodeSandbox example

https://codesandbox.io/s/jolly-rui-d3bps?file=/src/index.js

### Steps to reproduce

Observe how the sandbox has one `<Modal>` which is closed, but its `modalHeading` prop is oscillating every few seconds. Meanwhile the other `<Modal>` is open. Notice the flickering scrollbar on the right, and also the class `.bx--body--with-modal-open` being repeatedly added to and removed from the `<body>` element of the demo frame.

items.title: [a11y]: ComposedModal - VO - when closing modal, user becomes stuck on close button
items.body:
### Package

carbon-components-react

### Browser

Safari

### Operating System

MacOS

### Package version

10.55.0

### React version

16.9.0

### Automated testing tool and ruleset

Manual testing

### Assistive technology

iPhone 12 - VoiceOver

### Description

When using VO on iPhone in Safari, user gets stuck on the close button when they close the `ComposedModal`

One thing I did to try to fix this issue on my end, was to pass a function to the `buttonOnClick` prop of the `ModalHeader` component that would set the focus back to the trigger element on modal close. However, the `onBlur` of the `ComposedModal` interferes with this, triggering the `wrapFocus()` and sets the focus to an item within the modal (which at that point is closed).


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54281166/159930948-f1d44af0-1a38-41bf-8a1d-9d4899caccfb.mov

items.title: [a11y]: Focus on the less destructive action on a danger modal
items.body: ### Package carbon-components ### Browser Chrome ### Operating System MacOS ### Package version V11 ### React version V7.54.2 ### Automated testing tool and ruleset n/a ### Assistive technology n/a ### Description In a dialog/modal, the default focus should be set to the first focusable element, such as a text field in a form. However, in a danger modal, according to W3 guideline, "Focus is automatically set to the first focusable element inside the dialog, which is the "No" button. This is the least destructive action, so focusing "No" helps prevent users from accidentally confirming the destructive "Discard" action, which cannot be undone." (https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices/examples/dialog-modal/alertdialog.html) ### WCAG 2.1 Violation 2.4.3 Focus order ### CodeSandbox example n/a ### Steps to reproduce in Carbon's live demo for modal, opening a danger modal shows the default focus is set on the red "Save" button. The focus should be set on the Cancel button instead to prevent users from accidentally confirming the destructive action. ### Code of Conduct - [X] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/blob/f555616971a03fd454c0f4daea184adf41fff05b/.github/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) - [X] I checked the [current issues](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues) for duplicate problems

items.title: Modals have no easy way of showing the recommended loading state
items.body:
### Summary

The Modal guidelines recommend [2 variants of a loading state](https://carbondesignsystem.com/components/modal/usage/#loading), however neither are easy to accomplish with the (react) library out of the box.

### Justification

Developers should be enabled to achieve the recommended visual states, in the easiest way possible, to enable a consistent UX, as well as improving DX.

### Desired UX and success metrics

The Modals should have a trivial way of achieving all the properties of the recommended loading states.

### My proposal

The Modals should have a `loading` property that takes 3 values: `"none" | "inline" | "overlay"`, and a `loadingText` property that either shows on the overlay loader (if `loading === "overlay")`, or overrides the `submitButtonText` (if `loading === "inline"`) and disables the button while `loading !== "none"`.

### Required functionality

_No response_

### Specific timeline issues / requests

I think this should be included in the upcoming v11 release.

### Available extra resources

I am happy to attempt my first PR.

## Detailed description

> Describe in detail the issue you're having.

Because unique ids for Modal, Accordion and other components that need instance Ids are dynamically generated based on load order, if we add more Modals to our codebase, downstream snapshots will tag these ids as changed and require a update.  This is confusing to developers as they haven't updated any of those downstream components.  

> Is this issue related to a specific component?
any compnoent using the setupGetInstanceId method. 

Can we please add an optional id prop to each of these components, that if set is always used by the component (instead of the dynamically generated id).  This would allow us to create snapshots in a deterministic fashion that weren't reliant at runtime.

items.title: AVT 3 - Modal React Component: iOS Focus Trap

labels.name: severity: 2
labels.description: Affects major functionality, has a workaround

items.body:
**Environment**
iOS 12.2
Safari & VoiceOver

**Issue:**
1. With VoiceOver on, swipe left or right or use the arrow keys in quick nav mode until you find the button to activate the modal.
2. Double-tap on the button to launch the modal.
3. The close modal button will be announced and will have focus.
4. Swipe left and right to explore the modal, you can read the text and focus on the cancel and save buttons.
5. The issue is that navigation is not restricted to the modal only, once it is open there is no way to know if there is an open modal present, the user needs to remember it.

## Detailed description

> Describe in detail the issue you're having.

The overflow gradient is not rendered when the `enable-css-custom-properties` feature flag is enabled. The CSS rule for the gradient has an invalid value.

```background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom, rgba(var(--cds-ui-01, #f4f4f4), 0), var(--cds-ui-01, #f4f4f4));```

`rgba` expects four arguments so will not work with the `var` syntax.

> Is this issue related to a specific component?

`Modal`

> What did you expect to happen? What happened instead? What would you like to
> see changed?

As there is an issue using `transparent` as the start color in Safari, could another color custom property be added that has a `rbga` value? 

```
--cds-ui-01: #f4f4f4;
--cds-ui-01-transparent: rgba(244, 244, 244, 0);
```

```
-   background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom, $ui-01, $ui-01);
+   background-image: linear-gradient(to bottom, $ui-01-transparent, $ui-01);
```

 - Tooltip should be attached to the position of its icon and should move with it if icon moves

 - Google Chrome

> What offering/product do you work on?
 - Ibm cloud Power-iaas. This issue is causing many accessibility and responsivity problems as well as bad user experience and it is very blocking for our product 

## Steps to reproduce the issue
 - create a tooltip inside a body of a modal or side panel.
 - the modal or sidePanel body sould be scrollable and contains enough space to scroll
